intro: Mollugo glinus var. dictamnoides, commonly known as the creeping mouse-ear, is a low-growing, herbaceous plant native to the eastern United States. It features small, succulent leaves that are typically arranged in a rosette pattern, and it produces tiny, yellowish flowers in the spring. The plant is often found in moist, sandy soils along the edges of forests or in open woods. It has a shallow root system and is adapted to thrive in shaded to partially shaded environments. Its botanical characteristics make it a hardy, drought-tolerant species that is sometimes used in native plant gardens.
